articles.summary: Kingston, New York, has received a $538,409 state grant for its Food Scraps Compost Program, part of over $7.3 million awarded to municipalities across the state through the Climate Smart Communities grant program. The grant will be used to expand the program, which has significantly reduced the amount of food waste sent to the landfill. The program, launched in 2023, has been highly successful and has diverted 33.65 tons of food from the Seneca Meadows Landfill. The cost of disposing of food scraps costs $20 per ton per ton, compared to $115 per ton for disposing solid waste, reduces carbon emissions and reduces waste by fewer truck trips to the Senec landfill. With the grant, Kingston will implement a five-pronged organics diversion program.

articles.title: 5 things to know about Oregon’s vanishing kelp forests
articles.description: Underwater kelp forests along Oregon’s southern shore are disappearing at an alarming clip, according to new data by the Oregon Kelp Alliance.
articles.content:
Underwater kelp forests along Oregon’s southern shore are disappearing at an alarming clip, according to new data by the Oregon Kelp Alliance.

The statewide nonprofit quantified those seaweed decline... [1878 symbols]
articles.summary: Underwater kelp forests along Oregon's southern shore are rapidly decreasing, according to data from the Oregon Kelp Alliance. The group quantified these declines through extensive research, including 85 scuba dives, two dozen drone surveys, and analysis of aerial surveys and underwater surveys conducted by the state and several nonprofits. The kelp canopy declined by more than two-thirds between 2010 and 2022, with nearly 900 acres of kelp covering the equivalent of 680 football fields. The decreases occurred in reefs that historically were home to some of Oregon's most notable underwater forests. Researchers are now looking for ways to restore Oregon's kelp ecosystem, with the best hope being reintroducing sea stars back into the ecosystem.

articles.title: Essay
articles.description: The greenhouse gas warms the planet far more than carbon dioxide but dissipates more quickly. There are many promising ways to cut emissions.
articles.content: If greenhouse gases were prizefighters, methane would be a heavyweight—a powerful puncher that tires quickly. Pound for pound, it is 90 times stronger than carbon dioxide (CO ) at warming the Earth. B... [688 symbols]
articles.summary: Methane, a powerful greenhouse gas, is 90 times stronger than carbon dioxide (CO), but it is also shorter lived than CO and leaves the air naturally after only a decade. If we could eliminate all methane emissions from human activities, including agriculture, waste, and fossil fuels, the level of methane in Earth’s atmosphere would fall to preindustrial levels within a decade or two, reducing global warming by 0.5 of a degree Celsius. This would significantly aid efforts to keep increased global warming from all gases below 1.5 or 2 degrees.

"Not good, yeah," said J... [2432 symbols]
articles.summary: Residents of Colorado's Front Range have been huddled indoors due to smoke and ozone-laden air due to respiratory issues and health concerns. The Department of Public Health and Environment reported "unhealthy" air quality levels on the west and east sides of Denver, Boulder, Fort Collins, Greeley, and Colorado Springs. These conditions have led to increased short-term respiratory complaints and increased risk of stroke and heart attacks, according to Dr. Anthony Gerber, a professor of medicine and director of pulmonary research at National Jewish Health. The issue has been exacerbated by wildfires, wildfires in the Western US and Canada, leading to high ozone levels and challenges in reducing emissions from automobiles and power plants. Gerber also noted that as the population increases, there are now more people making pollutants.

articles.title: Scientists found a groundbreaking new reason to plant more trees
articles.description: Microbes living in tree bark are absorbing methane, a potent greenhouse gas, from the atmosphere on a massive scale, a study found.
articles.content:
• None Methane has 80 times the warming power of carbon dioxide over two decades.
• None Trees' methane absorption could be twice that of Arctic permafrost emissions.

Trees are a more powerful climat... [3556 symbols]
articles.summary: A study by the University of Birmingham has found that trees absorb methane from the atmosphere, a potent greenhouse gas that has 80 times the warming power of carbon dioxide over two decades. The study, led by Vincent Gauci, found that tree bark absorbs more methane than soil, the only other known natural sink on Earth. The findings were made over a decade, with researchers measuring methane from trees in countries such as Brazil, Peru, Panama, the UK, and Sweden. They found that while trees emit a little bit of methane at the bottom of their tree, they absorb more at the top of their trunk. The researchers also found that if all tree bark were laid flat, it could cover Earth's land surface and remove between 25 million tons and 50 million tons of methane.

articles.title: Scientists found a groundbreaking new reason to plant more trees
articles.description: Microbes living in tree bark are absorbing methane, a potent greenhouse gas, from the atmosphere on a massive scale, a study found.
articles.content: Trees are a more powerful climate solution than previously known.Microbes living in tree bark are absorbing methane, a potent greenhouse gas, from the atmosphere on a massive scale, a study published ... [3366 symbols]
articles.summary: A study by Vincent Gauci, a professor at the University of Birmingham, has found that trees absorb methane, a potent greenhouse gas, from the atmosphere on a massive scale. The study, published in Nature, found trees absorb more methane than soil, which is the only other known natural sink on Earth. The researchers measured methane from trees in countries such as Brazil, Peru, Panama, the UK, and Sweden. They found that while trees emit a little bit of methane, they absorb more when they go up the trunk. While tropical trees absorb the most methane, their woody surface makes them about 10% more climate-beneficial than previously thought. The findings helped close a discrepancy in the global methane budget. If all tree bark were laid flat, it could cover Earth's land surface, and it may be removing between 25 million tons and 50 million tons of methane.

articles.title: Royal Mint to stop making coins from scratch after 1,100 years
articles.description: A Royal Mint insider told This is Money it will now import coin 'blanks' from countries such as Germany and Turkey.
articles.content:
The Royal Mint plans to stop producing coins from scratch at its facility in Wales from December with staff diverted to mining gold from laptop circuit boards, This is Money can reveal.

As the oldest... [5075 symbols]
articles.summary: The Royal Mint is set to stop producing coins from scratch from its facility in Wales from December, with staff diverted to mining gold from laptop circuit boards. The oldest company in the UK, the Royal Mint, has been producing coins for over 1,100 years. Instead of producing its own coins from raw steel, the Mint will import 'blanks' from abroad when stocks are low. It will only imprint these blanks at its site in Llantrisant rather than making them from scratch. This comes as Treasury has no new orders for one and two pence coins this year due to a decline in cash use. The Royal Mint will still supply the UK market and is seeking to sell its facilities to produce coin blanks. As part of the shift towards gold recovery, 200 staff have been offered positions in the gold recycling plant.

articles.authorsByline: DREW LINDSAY of The Chronicle of Philanthropy
articles.title: Major funders bet big on rural America and ‘everyday democracy’
articles.description: Turner is co-director of the Mississippi Center for Cultural Production in the town of Utica, population 600, where his family has lived for eight generations.  The organization, better known as Sipp Culture, is helping breathe life into a region that’s seen schools, grocery stores, and factories shutter or leave.  While that may seem like traditional community development, a new philanthropic venture sees Turner as key to grand ambitions to shore up democracy.
articles.content: This photo provided by Sipp Culture shows farm apprentice Kira Cummings working on the Sipp Culture Community Farm in Utica, Miss., on April 21, 2022. Grocery stores in the area closed, so residents c... [8457 symbols]

entities.data: the Mississippi Center for Cultural Production
the Community Foundation of Greater Dubuque

articles.summary: The Trust for Civic Life has named 20 inaugural grantees in its bid to revitalize rural, often high-poverty towns, regions, and tribal areas. The trust sees small, local groups as modern versions of organizations that scholars have highlighted as a distinguishing feature of American democracy. The Trust announced $8 million in funding, the first installment of investments of $50 million over five years. Grantees exemplify what the trust calls “everyday democracy” as they bring people together to address fundamental concerns such as a fading industry, a dilapidated park, or access to quality health care. This is a rare investment by national philanthropy in small groups in rural America. Over the past few decades, major grantmakers have decreased investments in rural areas, largely due to the shift towards metropolitan regions.

articles.summary: Germany is leading the European Union's shift towards cleaner energy by investing in green hydrogen, produced through electrolysis driven by wind and solar power. This is part of a plan for a nationwide grid that will start commercial operations by 2032. The energy transition became urgent after Russia's gas supply stopped due to the Ukraine war. Industry leaders such as steelmakers Thyssenkrupp (TKAG.DE) and ArcelorMittal plan to invest billions of euros in decarbonising steel production, betting on hydrogen's availability. The total cost for the hydrogen network, including 9,666 kilometers of pipelines, is estimated at around 19.7 billion euros.

articles.title: You may soon drink purified wastewater. Here's how Arizona will ensure it's safe
articles.description: Cities all over Arizona are considering Advanced Water Purification. It's important to set rules that ensure this water is safe — and plentiful.
articles.content:
You may soon drink purified wastewater. Here's how Arizona will ensure it's safe

You might think that if we’re going to drink recycled wastewater, we should throw as many regulations at it as possibl... [3987 symbols]
articles.summary: The Arizona Department of Environmental Quality has developed draft regulations to ensure the safety of drinking purified wastewater from recycled wastewater. The regulations aim to make Advanced Water Purification a viable option for communities across the state, not just major cities like Phoenix and Scottsdale, but also smaller rural providers. The state's regulations are stringent but flexible, as they should be to protect public health, but how providers meet them can vary depending on the quality and quantity of wastewater treated. The draft regulations also outline monitoring and response times for contaminants found in the water. However, setting rigid standards on which tech is used and when in the process could require some providers to do more treatment than they need to clean their water to ultra-pure standards at a much higher cost than necessary. This could make it impractical for smaller, rural providers, particularly for communities that rely solely on groundwater.

Factors such as the sale of any vessel or acquisition could significantly impact the Company's business strategy, dry bulk and containers market conditions, and future debt obligations.

articles.title: Philippine oil tanker sinks in Manila Bay, raising fears of a possible major spill near the capital
articles.description: A Philippine oil tanker has sunk in Manila Bay after encountering huge waves. The coast guard is working to determine whether the vessel is leaking oil — in what could be a major spill — after it rescued 16 of 17 crew members in a nighttime operation.
articles.content: MANILA, Philippines (AP) — A Philippine oil tanker sank in Manila Bay early Thursday after encountering huge waves, leaving a crewman dead and 16 others rescued in a late-night operation by the coast ... [3663 symbols]

keywords.name: coast guard spokesperson Rear Adm. Armando Balilo

articles.summary: A Philippine oil tanker, the Terra Nova, has sunk in Manila Bay, raising concerns about a major oil spill near the capital. The ship was carrying 1.4 million liters (370,000 gallons) of industrial fuel oil when it was lashed by huge waves and took on water. One crewman was killed and 16 others were rescued in a late-night operation by the coast guard. The coast guard is also investigating whether the vessel is leaking oil, which could reach Manila. The sinking follows days of monsoon rains that left at least 22 people dead and displaced over half a million people. The Coast Guard is preparing for a major spill similar to one in February last year off Oriental Mindoro province.

The injunction was granted following an "escalation in the level of threat" to the power station. Lawyers for the company claimed that North Yorkshire Police advised them to seek an injunction following a specific threat of imminent environmental protest by the campaign group Reclaim the Power. The court did not cover a "strip of land" marked out for "peaceful protest". The injunction will be reviewed in 12 months.

articles.summary: The National Interagency Fire Center has reported that there are currently 79 large wildfires across the country, with fires burning in California, Oregon, Arizona, Washington and Canada. The largest active blaze in the U.S. was near the Oregon-Idaho border and was 0% contained, and had burned nearly 400 square miles. Oregon has 31 large active fires that have burned 791,653 acres (320,371 hectares). The largest fire in California is the Lake Fire in Santa Barbara, the largest in Arizona, followed by the Romero Fire west of Dudleyville. In Canada, there are about 430 active wildfires in British Columbia and 177 in neighboring Alberta. Unhealthy air pollution from wildfires has led to air quality alerts and advisories in regions of the western U., including Oregon, Nevada, Southeast, Central Oregon, Southern Idaho, and the Utah and Arizona Strip.

articles.summary: The construction of Clean Energy Fuels' renewable natural gas (RNG) production plant at South Fork Dairy in Dimmitt, Texas, US has begun. The new facility is set to be one of the largest of its kind in the US, with a capacity of approximately 2.6 million gallons of RNG production and will be integrated into Clean Energy's network of fuelling stations across the country. articles.summary: Fly-tippers have returned to the streets of Crosby, a suburb on the outskirts of Scunthorpe, where they have dumped more waste and white goods in a previously cleared alleyway. This comes after a massive council clean-up in May that removed 34 tons of rubbish from the area, following a two-day period of cleaning up the problem. The council, which spent two days clearing the rubbish, has caused local anger and anger. Councillor Rob Waltham, Leader of North Lincolnshire Council, expressed his anger over the incident, stating that the council is doing everything possible to catch these individuals in the act and enforce the maximum penalty of £1000. The previous clean up saw eight tonnes of 'bulky items' including 60 mattresses, 25 sofas and 40 items of white goods removed, nine tonnes of smaller items, 12 tonnes of general waste, and five tonnes of swept up rubbish such as litter and glass.

articles.title: Barbados debt-for-climate swap nears as EIB, IDB finalise guarantees
articles.description: The launch of a new "debt-for-climate" swap in Barbados appeared imminent on Thursday after the European Investment Bank (EIB) and Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) finalised a vital $300 million guarantee for the plan.
articles.content: LONDON, July 25 (Reuters) - The launch of a new "debt-for-climate" swap in Barbados appeared imminent on Thursday after the European Investment Bank (EIB) and Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) fin... [2027 symbols]
articles.summary: The European Investment Bank (EIB) and Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) have finalised a $300 million guarantee for a new "debt-for-climate" swap in Barbados. The deal will allow the Caribbean island nation to issue the equivalent of $295 million of sustainability-linked debt, with the EIB and IDB each providing $150 million guarantees. The savings will be used to upgrade sewage treatment plant upgrades and reduce pollution into the Caribbean. Barbados Prime Minister Mia Mottley described this as a "historic moment" for the island and a powerful model for other countries vulnerable to climate change. This deal is part of the EU's Global Gateway project, a bid to woo Global South countries that have long relied on China's Belt & Road Initiative for infrastructure needs.

articles.title: UK govt launches flagship green energy plan

articles.content:
Britain's new government wants to increase use of renewable energy (Andy Buchanan)

Britain's new Labour government launched its flagship green energy infrastructure plan on Tuesday, announcing a mult... [3699 symbols]
articles.summary: UK's new Labour government has launched its flagship green energy infrastructure plan, launching a multi-billion-pound partnership with the business arm of the royal family to develop offshore wind farms. Prime Minister Keir Starmer's government plans to establish Great British Energy, a publicly owned body called GB Energy, to spearhead funding in domestic renewable energy projects. The public financing of the body will be funded through windfall taxes levied on oil and gas companies. The government has allocated £8.3 billion ($10 billion) of public funds over the next five years to meet Britain's climate change targets and reduce reliance on foreign imports. GB Energy will also partner with the monarchy's land and property holdings company, the Crown Estate, which owns vast swathes of Britain's seabed. The Crown Estate estimates that its partnership will lease enough offshore land to produce up to 30 gigawatts of new energy, enough to power almost 20 million homes by 2030.

articles.title: Climate Crisis -- What Will You Do About Climate-Caused Human Migration?
articles.description: Because we seem to be trying to turn a planet that supports life into one that does not, I’m posting a question or topic here every week to see if together we can work out some nuts and bolts of ...
articles.content: Because we seem to be trying to turn a planet that supports life into one that does not, I’m posting a question or topic here every week to see if together we can work out some nuts and bolts of how t... [3841 symbols]
articles.summary: The author suggests that as humans respond to climate-caused human migration in different ways, historically, we tend to act differently to this phenomenon, including walls, castles, and pueblos, which are resource-intensive defensive measures that can be breached, bridged, and bypassed. These include hard borders, like the Great Wall of China, castles with moats, and walls that look impressive but don't accomplish much and keep societies from using their resources in positive ways. Historically, these include taking in the newcomers into the dominant culture, adopting their foods and music, and providing homes and jobs, forming a new, different whole. However, walls come up when a population has to migrate in a short period of time, leading to cultural breakdown. So far, this has led to increased border militarization and war, racism and demonization of the other, with sanctuary and aid groups underresourced and communities taking in families and individuals. Individuals need to push their communities towards this approach.

Each Olympic visitor is accountable for 100kg of CO2 emissions, a scientist... [4028 symbols]
articles.summary: A scientist from Polytechnique Montréal in Canada, Dr Anne de Bortoli, has warned that carbon emissions at the Paris 2024 Olympics will increase due to transport, food, energy generation, construction, transport, and construction. The maximum carbon budget for Paris 2024 has been set at 1.58 million tonnes of CO2 equivalent (Mt CO2 eq). This is an ambitious target for Olympic organisers, especially considering the Tokyo 2020 Games generated almost 2 Mt CO2. The exact carbon footprint of Paris 2024 will be known after the games, but it is estimated to be 1.6 MtCO2 eq for 13 to 16 million visitors, or around 100 to 125 kg CO2 emissions per person. De Bortol urges measures to limit global warming and comply with the Paris Agreement.

articles.title: Dorset Council declares nature emergency but what does it mean?
articles.description: The climate emergency declaration will affect Dorset Council's future decision making.

What does it mean to declare a nature emergency?

A nature emergency has been declared in Dorset following a vote by the new Liberal Democrat-led council. But what impact will it have on Dorset reside... [2049 symbols]
articles.summary: Dorset Council has declared a nature emergency, following a vote by the new Liberal Democrat-led council. The declaration means that the council will consider nature recovery in its decision-making and will commit to improving biodiversity on its land. It also includes creating wildlife corridors and working with landowners and parish councils to increase tree cover and "green our streets". The nature recovery strategy does not include an outright ban on glyphosates, but an amendment was passed to reduce use of the controversial weed killer. The Dorset Wildlife Trust (DWT) has praised the declaration as a "bold commitment to action", highlighting that one in 40 species previously recorded in Dorset are no longer present, and nearly 20 species of bee are nearly extinct.

articles.content: The Olympics are all about the unexpected. And for marathon swimmers and triathletes, that includes a notoriously unpredictable partner—the venue, which is typically an ocean, a lake or, in the case o... [7312 symbols]

entities.data: Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health
the University of Minnesota Medical School

articles.summary: The historic Seine, a water that has been contaminated for over 100 years, has been banned for swimming by Paris officials for more than a century. Olympic organizers have invested $1.5 billion into building a large tank under the Seine to hold stormwater during heavy rains and storms, and then the clean water is returned into the Seining. However, testing revealed unsafe levels of bacteria, particularly E. coli and enterococcus, which are responsible for gastrointestinal illnesses, including diarrhea, abdominal cramps, vomiting and nausea. The ultimate decision on whether to hold the marathon swimming and swimming portion of the triathlon in the river will be made by the respective sports’ governing bodies, depending on data gathered by Paris official. If the river continues to have fluctuating levels of pollutants, there are health risks athletes might face if officials decide the river is safe to swim in during the scheduled event.

articles.title: South Africa's climate action too slow to meet its bold pledges, says report
articles.description: South Africa, the world's 14th biggest carbon emitter, has made strong commitments to climate action but is moving too slowly to wean itself off coal and roll out renewables to meet them, a key report said on Thursday.
articles.content: JOHANNESBURG, July 25 (Reuters) - South Africa, the world's 14th biggest carbon emitter, has made strong commitments to climate action but is moving too slowly to wean itself off coal and roll out ren... [2181 symbols]
articles.summary: South Africa, the world's 14th biggest carbon emitter, is moving too slowly to meet its climate pledges, according to a report by the Presidential Climate Commission. The report, commissioned by the president's office but independent, called for a six-fold increase in the pace of renewable buildout. Despite being praised for its ambitious pledges to cut greenhouse gas emissions, South Africa's climate action is seen as being too slow. The country has admitted it will not meet its 2030 targets and has received $12 billion in loans from donors to fund its energy transition. However, the country has been increasing coal burners to address power shortages and has backtracked on pledges to shut down eight coal-fired power stations.

articles.title: South Africa's climate action too slow to meet its bold pledges, says report
articles.description: South Africa, the world's 14th biggest carbon emitter, has made strong commitments to climate action but is moving too slowly to wean itself off coal and roll out renewables to meet them, a key report said on Thursday.  Africa's most industrialised country has been lauded for making ambitious pledges to cut greenhouse gas emissions - which are higher even than far richer nations like France, Britain and Italy - and for producing a comprehensive plan to achieve them.  "Despite all the strong public support and policy commitments, we've got a huge discrepancy between that and what's actually happening," Melissa Fourie, one of the authors of the Presidential Climate Commission report, said at its launch in the commercial capital Johannesburg.

articles.summary: South Africa, the world's 14th biggest carbon emitter, is moving too slowly to meet its climate pledges, according to a report by the Presidential Climate Commission. The report, commissioned by the president's office but independent, stated that a six-fold increase in the pace of renewable buildout is needed. South Africa, which has been praised for its ambitious pledges to cut greenhouse gas emissions, is also moving too slow to wean itself off coal and roll out renewables to meet these targets. Despite this, South Africa has admitted it will not meet its 2030 targets and has signed a climate change act that sets caps for large emitters. The country has been using coal to address years of power shortages and has been investing heavily in renewable capacity.

articles.title: Ethiopia landslide death toll rises to 257, could reach 500: UN
articles.description: The landslide is the deadliest on record in Ethiopia, Africa’s second most populous nation which is often battered by climate-related disasters.
articles.content:
“The death toll has risen to 257,” as of July 24, the UN’s humanitarian agency OCHA said in statement citing local authorities. “The death toll is expected to rise to up to 500 people.”

Rescuers are ... [3479 symbols]
articles.summary: The death toll from landslides in southern Ethiopia has risen to 257 and could reach 500, according to the United Nations (UNICEF). The humanitarian agency OCHA warned that more than 15,000 people need to be evacuated due to the high risk of further landslides, including at least 1,320 children under the age of five and 5,293 pregnant women or new mothers. This is the deadliest on record in Ethiopia, which is often hit by climate-related disasters. The landslide site was sloped and "prone to disasters", according to Senait Solomon, head of communications for the South Ethiopia regional government. UN chief Antonio Guterres sent his condolences over the disaster.

articles.title: Bear-proof cannisters, hanging bags: Campers told to keep food away from Isle Royale’s wolves
articles.description: Juvenile wolves have been raiding the garbage dumpsters and food left behind by campers in this remote island wilderness.
articles.content: ISLE ROYALE, MI - National Park officials at Michigan’s remote wilderness island are again reminding campers they need to be vigilant to keep Isle Royale’s wolves from accessing food and trash near th... [4237 symbols]
articles.summary: National Park officials at Isle Royale, Michigan's remote wilderness island, have issued new guidelines to keep wolves from accessing food and trash near campgrounds. The instructions include instructions for visitors in some areas to use bear-proof cannisters and sturdy kennel boxes to store food while using their campsites. The guidelines are intended to ensure the safety of both wildlife and visitors. The largest wolf pack is located on the east end of the island. The new rules are similar to rules in other parks and wilderness areas where campers share the ecosystem with predators like wolves and bears. Isle Royale staff have implemented deterrent measures like hazing wolves near campground and putting electric fencing around garbage dumpster areas.

articles.summary: DTE Energy (NYSE:DTE) has reported its second quarter 2024 accomplishments, including the expansion of its Energy Efficiency Academy in Detroit and expanded to Grand Rapids. The company invested over $2 billion in the first half of the year, on track for a full year investment of over $4 billion. This investment is aimed at improving its electric and natural gas infrastructure and generating cleaner energy for communities it serves. Operating earnings for the second quarter were $296 million or $1.43 per diluted share, compared to 2023's $206 million. Other notable achievements included the creation of the Trenton Channel Energy Center, which will store 880 megawatt hours of electricity enough to power nearly 40,000 homes. DTE also helped make the 2024 NFL Draft a carbon-neutral success, partnering with the NFL and Visit Detroit to create a more sustainable environment for visitors.

articles.title: Experts share tips to stop green algae wreaking havoc on garden fences
articles.description: Green algae is a common garden problem - but experts claim there are numerous easy ways to deal with it.
articles.content: Green algae is a nightmare to deal with - especially when it comes to the garden. Unfortunately, damp wood is the perfect spot for these organisms to thrive, often giving your once polished fences a g... [2021 symbols]
articles.summary: Experts from GardenBuildingsDirect.co.uk have shared their tips on how to stop green algae from ruining garden fences. The algae, which thrive in damp wood, can lead to wood decay, surface discoloration, and slippery surfaces posing safety hazards. The experts suggest that removing algae from sheds, fences, and garden furniture is essential for prolonging the lifespan of these structures. They suggest using a homemade remedy that involves mixing one part white vinegar with two parts water to create an anti-algae solution for your fence. However, if this fails to work, use a pressure washer. The team also recommends using store-bought wood preservative. Regular maintenance can prevent algae growth and keep garden structures looking good year-round.

articles.summary: Plans for up to 100 homes in Bishops Wood, South Staffordshire, have been submitted to the council for consideration. The development, on land at Boscobel Lane, would deliver 40 affordable homes and include a shop, public open space, and a community orchard. The proposal argues that the "plentiful benefits" of the proposal outweigh any harm to the green belt. Existing trees and hedgerows will be incorporated into the proposals.

articles.title: California wildfires close more than 100 miles of Pacific Crest Trail
articles.description: More than 10 wildfires burning along on the West Coast are derailing the treks of thousands of thru-hikers on the 2,650-mile Pacific Crest Trail.
articles.content: The smattering of wildfires burning along the West Coast have shut down approximately 250 miles of the Pacific Crest Trail, wreaking havoc on the plans of thousands of thru-hikers trekking the famous ... [2996 symbols]
articles.summary: The Pacific Crest Trail Association (PCT Association) has reported that over 100 miles of California's hiking route have been closed due to wildfires that have affected thousands of thru-hikers. The fires, believed to be caused by heat waves, have closed about 110 miles of the trail in California and have led to a significant disruption to the 2,650-mile hiking route. The Pacific Crest Association manages thru hiker permits for the trail and has seen increased concern for hikers due to climate-fueled mega-fires that have scorched millions of acres of forest and burned across the Sierra crest. Local volunteers have been assisting hikers near the fire zone, transporting them 100 miles north to a trail junction at Seiad Valley.

articles.title: Life at 115F: a sweltering summer pushes Las Vegas to the brink
articles.description: Record heat is killing hundreds in Clark county. But one of America’s fastest-growing metro areas just keeps getting bigger
articles.content: Hot air wafted through the heavy, gold-lined doors of a Las Vegas casino as they opened, offering a reminder of a disaster quietly unfolding outside. Even though the sun had just set on an evening in ... [10197 symbols]
articles.summary: The summer heatwave in Las Vegas, known as the hottest on record, has pushed the desert metropolis to a dangerous level of heat. This summer saw a record seven days at 115F or higher and a record high of 120F. The city experienced a new record high in July, with temperatures reaching 120F in the month leading up to the all-time high of 115F. Meanwhile, Clark county, where Las Vegas is located, is bursting at the seams, with nearly 2 million people having moved to the area in the last 50 years and nearly a million more expected by 2060. The county has supported a federal bill that would open up 25,000 acres of the surrounding desert for housing and commercial development, and plans for a new airport in 2037. The record heat has been particularly impactful for the homeless, with over 5,000 people in the county estimated to be experiencing homelessness. Some residents have sought refuge in underground tunnels during the summer, risking the waters that surge through them during summer monsoons due to exposure to the heat.

articles.summary: Chemomab Therapeutics has announced positive Phase 2 trial results for its first-in-class monoclonal antibody, CM-101, in patients with Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (PSC). The study demonstrated anti-Fibrotic, Anti-Inflammatory and Anti-Cholestatic Activity across multiple components of the disease. The positive results have led to significant improvements in Liver Stiffness and Pruritis, a key PSC disease marker. The company plans to proceed with a Phase 3 trial in PSC in 2025. The double-blind placebo-controlled SPRING study involved 76 patients from the U.S., Europe and Israel.

The Supply Agreement follows Graphite's selection of a site for its proposed AAM facility in Warren, Ohio. articles.title: ‘What nature intended it to be’: NC lands historic EPA grant to fight climate change
articles.description: The $421 million grant is the largest the EPA has ever awarded to slash greenhouse gases with natural solutions like salt marshes and forests.
articles.content:
To cut carbon emissions, North Carolina and three nearby states are going to look to nature.

The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency has awarded the Atlantic Conservation Coalition a $421 million Cl... [6369 symbols]
articles.summary: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has awarded the Atlantic Conservation Coalition a $421 million Climate Pollution Reduction Grant, along with North Carolina, South Carolina, and Virginia. The grant is the largest the EPA has awarded for the use of natural solutions to combat climate change. North Carolina's portion of the award includes $50 million for "shovel ready" projects, $30 million for the N.C. Coastal Federation for restoration projects, and an additional $67.8 million for The Nature Conservancy to restore an estimated 33,500 acres of peatlands across North Carolina and Virginia, while protecting an additional 10,500 more acres. The projects are expected to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by over 22.7 million metric tons by 2050.

articles.summary: The Museum of Solutions in Mumbai, India, stands out with a solution-oriented approach that goes beyond traditional learn-through-play models. The 100,000 square foot museum, which houses four labs for kids ages two to 17, offers immersive learning experiences, interactive mazes, a library, recycling center, café, and workshops. The museum also houses a three-dimensional interactive maze and will host a Changemakers Panel, a first-of-its-kind initiative where children aged 11 to 14 will help design new programs and exhibits. Founder Tanvi Jindal Shete credits the museum's unique focus on children's voices.

articles.summary: A tanker carrying 1.4 million liters of industrial fuel capsized off the coast of Philippines, leaving one person dead and a vast oil spill. The Philippine-flagged MT Terra Nova was 3.6 nautical miles east off Limay, Bataan at 1:10 a.m. local time. The Coast Guard confirmed that 16 of the 17 crew members on board have been rescued, while four staff members are receiving medical attention. The oil spill is being managed by three 44-meter multi-role response vessels. The incident occurred amid heavy rainfall and heavy winds as Typhoon Gaemi and the seasonal torrential monsoon hit Manila.

Ed Miliband admitted bills might not go down any time soon as he unveiled a drive for more offshore wind.

The Net Zero Secretary has announced that the new state-owned Great British Energy firm will ... [5478 symbols]
articles.summary: Ed Miliband, the Net Zero Secretary, has announced the creation of state-owned Great British Energy (GB Energy), a firm that will partner with the King to help speed up building and develop offshore wind projects. The Crown Estate owns the vast majority of Britain's seabed and leases parts of it to wind farm operators. The move is part of a wider effort to reduce UK's reliance on energy imported from other countries by generating more of its own electricity. However, Mr Miliband admitted that it would take time for GB Energy to start generating returns within the lifetime of this Parliament. The government has set aside £8.3bn to invest in new wind farms and solar projects, which must be built before GB Energy can generate a return.

articles.summary: India's Adani Green Energy (ADNA.NS) reported a nearly doubling of its Q1 profit from the previous year, largely due to strong energy sales and increased operational capacity. The company's consolidated profit rose to 6.29 billion rupees ($75.1 million), from 3.23 billion rupee a year earlier. The quarter also included a severe heatwave that boosted the country's base power demand by 10%. Adani's energy sales increased by 22% year-on-year to 7,356 million units in the quarter, largely attributed to solar energy. The firm's operational capacity currently stands at 11.2 gigawatts, with solar energy accounting for almost two-thirds.

articles.title: Tanker sinks raising major oil spill fears
articles.description: Fears of a major oil spill after a larger tanker sank amid treacherous conditions in Manila Bay.
articles.content:
A Philippine oil tanker sank early Thursday in Manila Bay after being hit by huge waves, leading to fears of a major oil spill.

The Coast Guard rescued 16 of the 17 crew members in a nighttime operat... [2855 symbols]

keywords.name: Coast Guard spokesperson Rear Admiral Armando Balilo

articles.summary: A Philippine oil tanker, Terra Nova, sank in Manila Bay early Thursday amid fears of a major oil spill. The Coast Guard rescued 16 of the 17 crew members in a nighttime operation. The tanker was carrying approximately 1.4 million liters (370,000 gallons) of industrial fuel oil in watertight tanks when it encountered treacherous conditions. The crew's attempts to return to port were unsuccessful, leading to the vessel's sinking. An aerial survey identified a 2.3 mile-long oil slick near the site of the sinking, but initial reports suggest this could be from the tanker's engine fuel rather than the larger cargo. The search for the missing crew member is ongoing and the Coast Guard vessel BRP Melchora Aquino is currently in the area. There are concerns about potential environmental disaster if the oil leaks into Manila Bay, which could severely impact Manila's shorelines.

articles.title: Fuels & lubricants: navigating emissions reductions in off-highway mining fleets
articles.description: We explore GlobalData’s latest analysis on the challenges around emissions reductions in off-highway fleets, focusing on net-zero strategies, the low penetration of battery-electric machines, and the role of renewable fuels.
articles.content: Most mining companies are aiming to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050 or sooner, in line with the ambitions of the Paris Agreement. Meanwhile, many have interim targets to cut scope 1 and 2 emissions... [9433 symbols]
articles.summary: Most mining companies aim to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050 or later, in line with the Paris Agreement. Many have interim targets to reduce scope 1 and 2 emissions by between 30 and 50% by 2030. These targets are often based on the potential to transition from fossil-fuel-generated power to renewable energy. Harmonic Gold is aiming for a 63% decline in emissions by 2036, largely due to a move to renewables from coal-fired grid power in South Africa. A survey by GlobalData found that on-site renewable power is seen as the most viable option for minimising mine site emissions through to the end of the decade. Companies are adopting renewable diesel and biofuels as a “transition pathway” to achieve interim emissions targets, alongside other benefits. BHP has partnered with BP to trial the use of a blended HVO (hydrotreated vegetable oil) diesel at its Yandi iron ore mine in Western Australia’s Pilbara region.

articles.title: California and Hawaii lead charge against deep-sea mining of critical metals

articles.content:
Workers disembark from a research vessel in San Diego in 2021 after obtaining samples of soil, water and wildlife in the Clarion-Clipperton Zone of the Pacific Ocean.

As the global energy transition ... [9178 symbols]

entities.data: the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea

articles.summary: The International Seabed Authority is meeting in Jamaica to discuss the future of deep-sea mining, which is being criticised by environmental groups for damaging sea life. The United States has not signed the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, which created the authority. However, California and several other states have established their own bans and restrictions on seabed mining. California Assemblywoman Luz Rivas (D-North Hollywood), author of a 2022 law banning the practice in state waters, has called on President Biden to place a moratorium on such activity. Mining companies argue that the metals they plan to harvest, such as cobalt and nickel, will help grow the green economy and spare land habitats from disruption. Critics argue that deep sea extraction causes less environmental disruption than mining on land.

articles.title: The Trans Mountain contradiction: how can Canada lead on climate while doubling down on oil?
articles.description: Despite climate-friendly plans, the government’s controversial decision to take over the pipeline made it one of world’s biggest promoters of fossil fuel projects
articles.content:
Like all major rivers winding through the country, Canada’s most controversial oil pipeline is destined for the ocean.

The Trans Mountain pipeline crosses two provinces, threads a national park in th... [12011 symbols]
articles.summary: The Trans Mountain pipeline, Canada's most controversial oil pipeline, has been completed after a decade of protests and construction delays. The controversial project crosses two provinces, crosses a national park in the Rocky Mountains, dips underneath bodies of water and passes through dozens of First Nations communities before terminating at a sprawling oil storage facility on the Pacific coast. Despite promises of strong climate action and billions in fossil fuel investments, critics argue that the government has provided massive government subsidies to the oil industry at a time when the planet needs to move away from fossil fuels. The project was initially proposed by Texas company Kinder Morgan in 2012 to triple the existing capacity of a pipeline it bought in 2005. However, delays, cost overruns and inflation have pushed the project far above initial estimates. The cost is now expected to exceed C$25bn.

articles.title: Global Heating Is No Longer a Tomorrow Problem. It’s Today’s.
articles.description: Monday was the hottest day in recorded history, and it’s only going to get worse. We’re not prepared for the public-health peril.
articles.content: For decades, global warming was widely seen as a tomorrow problem, something for our hapless grandchildren to worry about. But with heat records tumbling relentlessly, it’s becoming clear that tomorro... [566 symbols]
articles.summary: The average global temperature reached 17.15 degrees Celsius (62.87F) on Monday, the hottest day in recorded history, according to the EU's Copernicus Climate Change Service. This surpasses the previous record set on Sunday. This makes it clear that global warming is no longer a tomorrow problem, but a serious issue that has been foreseen for decades. The EU’s Copernication Climate Change service reports that the average global temperatures hit 17.16 degrees Celsius, breaking a record set by Sunday. The climate change service suggests that we are not ready for the heat and that we may not be ready for it.

articles.title: What to know about Project 2025’s plan for agriculture, and how it could lead to ‘real chaos’
articles.description: Steep increases in logging. An end to federal environmental enforcement for farms. Work requirements for food aid. Fewer school meals for children. And the demolition of the network of farm subsidi…
articles.content: Steep increases in logging. An end to federal environmental enforcement for farms. Work requirements for food aid. Fewer school meals for children. And the demolition of the network of farm subsidies ... [12931 symbols]
articles.summary: Conservative groups have developed a plan for American agriculture under Project 2025, which includes steep increases in logging, work requirements for food aid, fewer school meals for children, and the elimination of farm subsidies. The proposal is a long shot even if Republicans take control of the government. It would face a confrontation with urban Democrats and a polarized Congress, as well as some of the most powerful players in the Republican coalition. A spokesperson for House Agriculture Committee Chair Glenn Thompson (R-Pa.) dismissed the Project 2025 vision as an "obscure think tank paper" that didn't represent the chair, committee, or any of our future plans. The agriculture section of Project 2025 also proposes moving SNAP from the U.S. Department of Agriculture to Health and Human Services and ending government subsidies for crop insurance.

articles.summary: The Houston area's electric utility, CenterPoint Energy, has been criticized by the state for its handling of Hurricane Beryl power outages, which left more than 2.6 million Texas power customers without electricity for days following the storm. The company was accused of failing to prepare adequately for the storm, communicate clearly with customers and restore power efficiently. The Public Utility Commission in Texas, which oversees electricity rates and oversees utilities like CenterPoint, could fine CenterPoint with a fine for its poor handling of the situation. The storm's aftermath highlighted the need to strengthen the state's electrical distribution infrastructure against future storms and hurricanes.

articles.summary: YKK has reported a 56.2% decrease in its Scope 1 and 2 emissions and a 32.7% reduction in its emissions compared to its baseline in FY2023. The manufacturer has increased its use of renewable energy, switching to 100% renewable energy at an additional six sites in the past fiscal year, giving YKK a total of 37 sites using only green energy. The company's overall renewable energy use has also increased from 46.1% in 2022 to 56.5% in 2025. YKK plans to continue focusing on climate change, biodiversity, and resource recycling as part of its Sustainability Vision 2050 strategy. A more detailed report on its progress will be released in August 2024.
